text: Im surprised by the negative reviews, we really enjoyed it. Full of suspense and fun action scenes.
I have no idea why so many people dogged on this movie.  It's a damn fun popcorn action flick.

Liam Neeson has carved out a very particular niche in Hollywood over the past two decades. Ever since Taken cemented him as an unexpected action star, studios have been eager to replicate that formula, often at the expense of originality. The Ice Road is yet another entry in this growing list of Neeson-led thrillers, and while it isn’t unwatchable, it does little to break new ground.

The film positions Neeson as a rugged hero—once again a man pushed into dangerous circumstances where his grit, determination, and physicality are put to the test. The problem is that we’ve seen this exact template before, and not just once. Much of the narrative feels copy-and-paste, as though the script was tailored specifically to Neeson’s strengths without any effort to innovate or challenge him. Instead of a story designed to grip the audience, it feels more like a vehicle designed to keep Neeson in familiar territory.

The direction compounds this issue. Rather than crafting suspense or giving the audience a reason to invest emotionally, the film leans heavily on recycled tropes and set pieces. What could have been an intense, claustrophobic survival thriller set against the unforgiving backdrop of icy roads instead plays out like a routine action flick with little imagination. Casting choices don’t help either—several supporting roles feel unnecessary, more like filler than purposeful additions to the story, dragging down the momentum.

The screenplay is perhaps the weakest link. You can almost sense the writer bending the narrative to fit Neeson’s established persona rather than focusing on crafting a compelling, layered story. This approach leaves the film feeling hollow. A more daring choice might have been to cast against type or shift the focus to fresh character dynamics, but instead the script doubles down on predictability.

That being said, Neeson himself remains committed. At nearly 70, he still brings physicality and gravitas to the role, and his mere presence can elevate otherwise thin material. For diehard fans of his action work, The Ice Road offers more of the same—familiar rhythms, familiar stakes, and familiar thrills. There is comfort in that predictability, and some viewers may appreciate it.

For others, however, the lack of creativity will be hard to ignore. The Ice Road isn’t a terrible film, but it’s a forgettable one. It underscores both Neeson’s remarkable longevity as an actor and the risk of creative stagnation when a formula is repeated too often.

The Ice Road is one of those movies that feels like it had the potential to be great but got stuck somewhere in production limbo. Liam Neeson does his thing, gruff, determined, intense, and Amber Midthunder was a solid match beside him. But honestly, Marcus Thomas as Gurty? He stole the whole thing. His character had heart, depth, and actual emotional pull, which is more than I can say for most of the others. The story was serviceable, but the direction had no idea where it was going half the time. Some scenes were edited like the camera operator forgot they were filming an action thriller and thought they were making a home video.

Visually, it was a letdown. For a 2021 release, you’d expect way better CGI. The sky looked like it was slapped on in MS Paint and stayed frozen the entire time, even the clouds refused to act. That said, the score surprised me. I’m a sucker for intense, cinematic music, and this one delivered those epic vibes just when things started to fall apart. If they had tightened up the directing and fixed the visual mess, it could’ve been a whole different ride. But hey, at least Gurty kept me from bailing early.

THE ICE ROAD is a serviceable weekday action-thriller, with a decent premise and enough requisite twists to keep the stakes high. In execution and pacing, however, the movie lacks a certain commitment and momentum, and thus feels at times like everyone is just going through the motions. It's not quite the action film that ice road truckers deserve, but it is an acceptable popcorn flick, and apparently a sequel is in the works.
